title: Bricks and Walnuts
text:
← Back to Poems

There are birds in the neighbor’s tree, it’s the same tune from last year, I almost forgot birds could sing, summer has been too long and quiet, ever since the gardeners became barbers.
In the heat as the kitchen swelled, we danced and wrote notes, bouncing ideas, listening to the calls of jittery, young babes, being fed and cared for by their mothers.
Their nest reminded me of a street I’ve lived on, a place lined with rows of crying pink trees, and tall silver walls stuffed with a mixture of families, a home overfilled with life like a pregnant belly button.
Landlords demand a rent, wrote a letter, Dear tenants-Evacuate. As if homelessness is an alternative.
Birds don’t pay rent and neither should you, on land that is the property of soil and carcass.
You’ve been too quiet this summer, it may be time to begin again.

title: Water
text:
← Back to Poems

Water red as a beet, that’s never kissed skies, but has kissed animals’ feet.
It kisses them with knives, with red lips, thunderous lips, cancerous lips that steal lives.
A bison walks and splashes, ignoring the local vultures, the molding of birds and bats.
Plus, the flamingos, bright pink, frozen and displayed like glass.
There is rope around a neck, and blood stains in the past.
There’s blood by their head, as they are stuck in battle, stuck as gum dressed in dread.
Nothing moves or progresses, but the breath of peace, ound in complete stillness.
Shaking off the lake’s clay, dusting off the red mineral, just to survive another day.

title: Poetry
text: The four excerpts below are from my poetry book titled Bullseye Tiger that I released briefly on Amazon in 2021. I chose to share these because they contain elements of nature, environmentalism, and justice — the themes I’ve studied at UCSB the past two years. In each poem, nature is the heart of the writing and advocate for the injustices that burden both humans and animals.

title: Poetry
text:
Gallery
###Bullseye Tiger: A Collection of Poems

title: At Rest
text:
← Back to Poems

On planet Earth, I watched your eyes, land on beauty, inhale inspiration, as one of a kind, can’t be cloned, replicated or duped, only one world, where you exist, to ruminate quietly.

title: Tourist
text:
← Back to Poems

There are colors in the vast cosmos, that don’t compare to the hues around you, because I have seen only darkness up there, while your skin reminds me of coffee beans, and a caramel candy rivaling your sweetness.
You persuade me with your sights, settling for sunsets that meet river water, where wildlife buzzes along our shoulders, sniffing for food or lodging— maybe forgiveness, until it pleads to us in bloody bleats and huffs.
The animals ask for gentleness in humanity, since rumors have spread in a packed form, resembling light that trickles in so slightly, with descriptions of mankind’s treacheries, the tenacity-abandon then colonize elsewhere.

title: Projects
text:
On this page, I focus on the projects that stem from my life in academia as a vegan person and a yogi enthusiast. I have been challenged by my professors to utilize my passion and skills to create meaningful projects that can extend outside the classroom into the work field without sacrificing ourselves as individuals. Thankfully, I have many passions, interests, hobbies, and dreams to generate multiple projects throughout my years at UCSB.




For my Critical Thinking course (ES 40), we were tasked to do a research project of our choice and interest throughout the entire quarter. As a person who was majoring in environmental studies, I was open to hearing from classmates and other peers about their dietary choices and conflicting environmental beliefs. I did research on the impact that both the agricultural and livestock industry have on the environment and the choices individuals can make to lessen it from their own home. I provided perspectives from different backgrounds, both cultural and economical through personal interviews as to provide insight on the barriers that may be preventing environmentally conscious people from lessening their animal-based choices. I also highlight local resources and aid for those who are seeking to start their own personal journey of reducing their carbon foot-print or just lower their animal-based food intake.
Below is my research-based documentary:










For my Data Science class, we were tasked with logging personal data from our lives over the course of the quarter (roughly 30 days). I decided to analyze my yoga routine and how it affects my chronic back pain. I tracked the days I did or didn’t practice yoga and recorded my pain levels using a scale from 1 to 10.
Overall, the project was a powerful motivation to care for both my mental and physical health while learning how to work with real data. I’ve found that yoga and consistent movement can significantly reduce my pain. Unsurprisingly, the data showed that the days I skipped yoga were also the days I experienced the highest levels of discomfort.

library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(plotly)
library(htmlwidgets)


mydata <- read.csv("Data.csv") |>
  clean_names() |>
  mutate(
    tooltip_text = paste0(
      "Yoga Session: ", did_you_do_yoga, "<br>",
      "Pain Level After: ", pain_level_after)
  )

p <- ggplot(mydata, aes(
  x = did_you_do_yoga,
  y = pain_level_after,
  color = pain_level_after,
  text = tooltip_text
)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.15, size = 2.5, alpha = 0.6) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point", fun = mean, color = "#4a4a4a", size = 3) +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "#f9f871", high = "#7c3f98") +  # yellow to purple gradient
  labs(
    x = "Did You Do Yoga?",
    y = "Pain Level After Yoga",
    color = "Pain Level"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 13) +
  theme(
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "#ffe6eb", color = NA),        # baby pink background
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "#ffffff", color = "#ffb6c1"), # white panel with pink border
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "#ffccd5"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

ggplotly(p, tooltip = "text") |>
  layout(
    hoverlabel = list(font = list(size = 14)),
    annotations = list())

title: About Me
text:
There’s a whole multitude of hobbies, passions, and interests that I hold dearly to my heart. I would love to display it all for everyone, but the three things that create who I am to my core is: Traveling, Veganism, and my dog Raaja.

My Adventures around the world
Since I was a kid, traveling has been on my mind. Due to my family originating from parts of Mexico, South Korea, Portugal, and Spain. I have always had a great sense of wanderlust. I wanted to witness the childhood of my mother from Jalisco, Mexico or the lands my grandmother left in South Korea. As of today, I have traveled to four different countries: France, Germany, Switzerland, and (of course) Mexico! Each place was magnetic and beautiful in its own unique way. The way of living is different in each place. My most memorable travel was to Lyon and Paris France for my birthday in 2022. While there, we had the chance to travel to Genevieve, Switzerland which was a large hub of shopping and dinning. The best part about traveling is getting to eat the local food and having a new scenery enter your life for a brief moment.



Lyon, France (2022)





Tulum, Mexico (The Ruins,2025)




My Vegan Lifestyle
I wasn’t born into a vegan life; I adopted one. I have always had a great interest in reducing my meat intake, cutting out dairy for health reasons, and just not harming animals in general, but never took the plunge until three years ago. If my teenage self could see me, I wish I could tell her that we did it! People may think it’s just changing the diet, but it’s other things too like not buying fur, wool, or leather. My vegan lifestyle blends very well with my academic interests and I have had the chance to explore environmental veganism due to my major. There are many challenges that come with being vegan as the food may not be so easily accessible such as animal-based food, but with time and experience those challenges have become minimal.



Homemade and Restaurant




My dog Raaja
I am blessed to have amazing friends and family in my life, but having a dog is like having a guardian angel on Earth. Raaja was found deserted in front of a kill shelter for animals in Downey, California on December 1, 2015 which is my birthday. The very next day, wanting a dog out of nowhere, I visited SEACCA and fell immediately in love with a small golden puppy roughly four months old. Unfortunately, there was a long list of people waiting to adopt him. Nonetheless, I add my name to it. The next day I went to visit again and waas told that I was the only one there for him. I was called to know that I was the only one interested in him which meant I get to have him. Paying the small fee, I got to take him home and dubbed him with the name Maharaaja. Ever since then, he has been the best companion in my life. He goes everywhere with me, to the store, to lunch, and sometimes to class too! He is naturally trained and has a bad habit of running away from home. Not So Fun Fact: He was gone for nine months. Actual Fun Fact: He loves flowers and eating chips!



Maharaaja (2019)

title: Monique Allyson Hernandez
text:
Hi, welcome to my page!
I am a proud Gaucho, graduating class of 2025 this spring and will be departing happily with a B.S. in Environmental Studies. I am an advocate for sustainability and currently practice a vegan lifestyle which is integrated into my work through research and creative projects. Utilizing both my scientific and humanities background, I combine research with documentaries, poetic writings, and podcast. I have enjoyed working closely with classmates to create projects and presentations together throughout my academic career at UCSB.
